Graphical abstract Highlights ► Notable activity for ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization by CpTiCl2[1,3- t Bu2(CHN)2CN]. ► Unique effect of N-substituents for the activity in ethylene, styrene polymerizations. ► Living ethylene/styrene copolymerizations attained by Cp′TiCl2[1,3- t Bu2(CHN)2CN]. ► Drastic ligand effect: imidazolin-2-iminato vs imidazolidin-2-iminato analogues. Ethylene copolymerization with 1-hexene, styrene using half-titanocenes containing 1,3-dialkyl- and 1,3-diarylimidazolin-2-iminato ligands, Cp′TiCl2[1,3-R2(CHN)2CN] [Cp′=Cp (1), t BuC5H4 (2); R= t Bu (a), 2,6- i Pr2C6H3 (b)], have been explored in the presence of MAO cocatalyst. Complex 1a exhibited remarkable catalytic activity for ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization, affording ultrahigh molecular weight copolymers with uniform molecular weight distributions (M n =1.07–1.31×106, M w/M n =1.43–1.82). An opposite trend for effect of N-substituents in 1a,b toward the activity in ethylene and styrene homopolymerization was observed. The ethylene/styrene copolymerizations afforded poly(ethylene-co-styrene)s with uniform compositions and the polymerization by the t Bu analogues (1a,2a) proceeded in a living manner with moderate activities, whereas the imidazolidin-2-iminato analogues, CpTiCl2[1,3-R2(CH2N)2CN] (R= t Bu, Ph, 2,6-Me2C6H3), afforded a mixture of copolymer and homopolymers or exhibited negligible activity under the same conditions. Keywords Homogeneous catalysis Titanium Half-titanocene Ethylene Styrene 1 Introduction The design of efficient molecular catalysts for precise olefin polymerization attracts considerable attention in the field of organometallic chemistry, catalysis, and of polymer chemistry [1–7]. Modified half-titanocenes containing anionic donor ligands of the type, Cp′TiX2(Y) (Cp′=cyclopentadienyl group, X=halogen, alkyl, Y=aryloxo, ketimide, phosphinimide, etc.), exemplified in Chart 1 , are promising candidates [5,7–19], especially for the syntheses of new polymers by ethylene copolymerizations [9,13]. We already demonstrated that efficient catalysts for the desired ethylene copolymerizations with (sterically encumbered) α-olefins [9b,c,g,i,j,l,m,13b,g,h], styrene [9a,d,13c,e,16b], cyclic olefins [9e,f,h,13d,f,16b] can be tuned by ligand modifications (Cp′, Y): the anionic donor ligand strongly affects the comonomer incorporation [5]. Therefore, exploring the role of the anionic donor ligand should be important for designing efficient catalysts for precise olefin copolymerization directed toward the synthesis of new polymers by incorporation of new comonomers. Half-titanocenes containing imidazolin-2-iminato ligands, Cp′TiCl2[1,3-R2(CHN)2CN] [Cp′=Cp (1), t BuC5H4 (2); R= t Bu (1,3-di-tert-butylimidazolin-2-imide, a), 2,6- i Pr2C6H3 (1,3-diisopropylphenyl-imidazolin-2-imide, b)], are known to exhibit high catalytic activities for ethylene polymerization in the presence of methylaluminoxane (MAO) [19], affording ultrahigh molecular weight polymers [19b]. Using ligands of this type is promising, because these ligands have been widely used for the preparation of early transition metal complexes due to their unique ability to act as a strong 2σ,4π-electon donors toward early transition metals and/or metals in a higher oxidation state [19,20]. Moreover, we recently reported ethylene polymerization, syndiospecific styrene polymerization, and ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization using the Cp′-iminoimidazolidide (imidazolidin-2-iminato) analogues [15,21], CpTiCl2[1,3-R2(CH2N)2CN] (1c-e) [R= t Bu (c), Ph (d), 2,6-Me2C6H3 (e)], in the presence of MAO, and demonstrated that effective catalyst precursors for the desired polymerization could be tuned by variation of the ligand substituents [21]. In this paper, we explore ethylene copolymerization using half-titanocenes containing imidazolin-2-iminato ligands (1a,b,2a) in detail [21]. In particular, we wish to present that these complexes exhibit notable catalytic activities for copolymerization of ethylene with α-olefins (1-hexene, 1-dodecene), and superior catalyst performance in the (living) copolymerization of ethylene with styrene (Scheme 1 ) [22]. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Ethylene polymerization and copolymerization of ethylene with 1-hexene, 1-dodecene using half-titanocenes containing imidazolin-2-iminato ligands–MAO catalyst systems Ethylene polymerizations using half-titanocenes containing 1,3-substituted imidazolin-2-iminato ligands, Cp′TiCl2[1,3-R2(CHN)2CN] [Cp′=Cp (1), t BuC5H4 (2); R= t Bu (1,3-di-tert-butylimidazolin-2-imide, a), 2,6- i Pr2C6H3 (1,3-diisopropylphenyl-imidazolin-2-imide, b)], were conducted in toluene at 25°C in the presence of MAO. MAO white solid (d-MAO), which was prepared by removing AlMe3 and toluene from the commercially available samples (PMAO-S, 6.8wt% in toluene, Tosoh Finechem Co.), was chosen in this study, because it was effective in the preparation of high molecular weight ethylene/α-olefin copolymers with unimodal molecular weight distributions when the Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) was used as the catalyst precursor [8b]. The polymerization conditions (amount of titanium charged) were optimized on the basis of polymer yields (50–180mg). The results are summarized in Table 1 . It turned out that the activities were strongly affected by the amount of Al in the mixture rather than by the Al/Ti molar ratios (Fig. 1 , Table 1). Rather high activities were observed if the t Bu analogues (1a,2a) were conducted in the presence of MAO with small amount (runs 2, 13), and the activity of Cp′TiCl2[1,3-R2(CHN)2CN] increased in the order (under the optimized conditions): 2780kg-PE/mol-Tih (1b, run 8)<51,000 (1a, run 2)<66,000 (2a, run 13). The order is the same as that reported previously [19b], and the results may suggest that an electronic factor in the N-substituent (and Cp′) would play a role (1a > 1b; 2a > 1a). The resultant polymers were insoluble for ordinary GPC analysis (in o-dichlororbenzene at 140°C) probably due to their ultrahigh molecular weights, as reported previously [19b]. The selected polymerization results (by 1a,b,2a) under the optimized conditions are summarized in Table 2 . The results obtained for the Cp-1,3-imidazolidin-2-iminato analogues, CpTiCl2[1,3-R2(CH2N)2CN] (1c–e) [R= t Bu (c), Ph (d), 2,6-Me2C6H3 (e), Chart 2 ] [21], are also summarized for comparison. It turned out that 1a showed the highest catalytic activity among the Cp analogues and the activity increased in the order: 2220 (1e), 2580 (1d), 2780 (1b)<12,720 (1c)<51,000 (1a). It also turned out that the ligand substitution affected the activity, and the t Bu analogue (1a,1c) showed higher catalytic activities than the phenyl analogues (1b,d,e), and the fact may suggest that a stabilization of the active site by a more electron-releasing substituent is important for exhibiting high activity [8,19b,21]. Note that the imidazolin-2-iminato analogue (1a) showed higher catalytic activity than its imidazolidin-2-iminato congener (1c), and the t BuC5H4 derivative (2a) showed the highest catalytic activity. Copolymerizations of ethylene with 1-hexene and 1-dodecene were conducted under optimized conditions (Al/Ti molar ratios in Table 1). These copolymerizations were terminated at the initial stage, and termination with the comonomer conversion less than 10% should be very important to obtain the copolymers with uniform composition distribution and/or to evaluate the catalyst performance (r E, etc. shown below). The result obtained for CpTiCl2(NC t Bu2) under similar conditions [13b] is also mentioned for comparison. The results are summarized in Table 3 [23]. The catalytic activities in the ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization of CpTiCl2[1,3- t Bu2(CHN)2CN] (1a) were higher than those of the t BuC5H4 analogue (2a), CpTiCl2[1,3- t Bu2(CH2N)2CN] (1c) which showed better catalyst performance among the Cp-imidazolidin-2-iminato analogues (1c–e) [21]. The resultant polymers especially prepared by 1a,b and by 2a possessed ultrahigh molecular weights with uniform molecular weight distributions (M n =8.8–15.7×105, M w/M n =1.43–2.61). The activities were affected by ethylene pressure, and the 1-hexene content in the copolymer increased upon increasing the 1-hexene concentration. Both 1a and 2a were also effective for the ethylene/1-dodecene copolymerization, affording the copolymers with unimodal molecular weight distributions; the activities by 1a,2a in the copolymerization with 1-dodecene seemed somewhat higher than those in the copolymerization with 1-hexene (runs 20 and 23, runs 28–31, respectively). However, the activity of 1a was lower than that of the Cp-ketimide analogue (run 32), and the 1-hexene content in the resultant copolymer by 1a (estimated by 13C NMR spectra) were lower than those by 1c, and the Cp-ketimide analogue under the same conditions (runs 20, 25, 32) [23]. Fig. 2 shows 13C NMR spectra for resultant poly(ethylene-co-1-hexene)s and poly(ethylene-co-1-dodecene) prepared by 1a, 2a–MAO catalyst systems [23]. In all cases, resonances ascribed to two, three 1-hexene repeat units (Sαα, Tδδ, Tβδ) were observed. Although the 1-hexene contents in the copolymers were close, the intensitites ascribed to 1-hexene repeat/alternating sequences by 1a and 2a are different. This fact might support that 1a showed better 1-hexene incorporation than 2a (Fig. 2a and b). Moreover, resonances ascribed to isolated 1-dodecene incorporation in addition to trace amounts of resonances ascribed to alternating and/or repeat 1-dodecene incorporation were observed in the copolymer prepared by 2a–MAO catalyst (Fig. 2c) [23]. This result also suggests that incorporation of 1-dodecene seems more difficult than that of 1-hexene due to the steric bulk (butyl branch vs decyl branch). Table 4 summarizes triad sequence distributions, the dyads, and r E·r H values (E=ethylene, H=1-hexene) estimated based on 13C NMR spectra for poly(ethylene-co-1-hexene)s prepared by Cp′TiCl2[1,3-R2(CHN)2CN] [Cp′=Cp (1), t BuC5H4 (2); R= t Bu (a), 2,6- i Pr2C6H3 (b)]–MAO catalyst systems [24–26]. The result obtained for CpTiCl2[1,3- t Bu2(CH2N)2CN] (1c) [21], and CpTiCl2(NC t Bu2) (Cp-Ket) [13b] are also shown for comparison. The resultant r E·r H values of 1a,b,2a (r E·r H =0.63–0.71) were rather large compared to that of Cp-Ket (0.35, run 32). Although these values are somewhat lower than that of 1c (0.94, run 31), these findings indicate that 1-hexene incorporation in the copolymerization proceeds in a random manner (1-hexene incorporations were random due to that the r E·r H values were close to 1), as observed in ordinary metallocenes and linked half-titanocenes [24]. Moreover, the r E·r D values (E=ethylene, D=1-dodecene) by 2a was 0.17, indicating that the copolymerization did not proceed in a random manner due to steric bulk of the decyl branch in 1-decene (difficulty for incorporation of 1-dodecene repeatedly). The r E values in the ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization by 1a,b,2a were 9.56–9.62 (1a), 11.8 (1b), 17.4 (2a), respectively, and the r E values were affected by the ligand sets employed: 1a showed better 1-hexene incorporation than 1b,2a. These values were much larger than those obtained for 1c (4.95, run 31), Cp-Ket (4.5, run 32) [13b], [Me2Si(C5Me4)(N t Bu2)]TiCl2 (3.42) [9c], and Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (2.70) [9b,c], but were similar to those of ordinary ansa zirconocenes [r E =8.2–18.9 by linked bis(indenyl)-zirconium complexes in ethylene/1-octene copolymerization] [24]. These results therefore suggest that the present catalysts show less efficient 1-hexene incorporation. It might be interesting that r E values estimated for 2a in the copolymerization between 1-hexene and 1-dodenece were close (r E =17.4, 18.1, respectively, runs 29–30), although the value in the ethylene/1-dodenece copolymerization was larger than those observed for the aryloxo analogue (3.71–3.95), [Me2Si(C5Me4)(N t Bu2)]TiCl2 (4.26–4.31) [9m]. The results also indicate that precise ligand modifications are important for the copolymerization to proceed with uniform catalytically active species as well as with moderate comonomer incorporation. 2.2 Syndiospecific styrene polymerization and ethylene/styrene copolymerization by half-titanocenes containing imidazolin-2-iminato ligands–MAO catalyst systems We previously demonstrated that efficient catalyst precursors for the syndiospecific styrene polymerization using modified half-titanocenes, Cp′TiX2(Y) (Cp′=cyclopentadienyl group, X=halogen, alkyl, Y=anionic anicillary donor ligand), can be tuned from the efficient catalyst precursors for the ethylene polymerization by the ligand modification [5]. For example, Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) is an effective catalyst precursor for ethylene polymerization, whereas (tert-BuC5H4)TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) is an effective catalyst precursor for syndiospecific styrene polymerization [9a]. Moreover, we reported that the activity in styrene polymerization of CpTiCl2[1,3-R2(CH2N)2CN] [R= t Bu (1c), Ph (1d), 2,6-Me2C6H3 (1e)]–MAO catalyst systems increased in the order: 50sPS/mol-Tih (1c)<80 (1d)≪260 (1e, R=2,6-Me2C6H3), although the observed activities of 1e were lower than those of the CpTiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) or CpTiCl3–MAO catalysts [27]. We thus conducted styrene polymerization in the presence of MAO at 25°C, and the results of the experiments conducted under certain Al/Ti molar ratios (optimized ratio in ethylene polymerization shown in Table 1) are summarized in Table 5 . The resultant polymers possess relatively high molecular weights with unimodal molecular weight distributions (M n =4.43–5.25×104, M w/M n =1.59–1.71) as well as with almost perfect tacticity, suggesting that these polymerizations proceeded with uniform catalytically active species. The activity in the polymerization of Cp′TiCl2[1,3-R2(CHN)2CN] [Cp′=Cp (1), t BuC5H4 (2); R= t Bu (a), 2,6- i Pr2C6H3 (b)] catalyst systems increased in the order: 40kg-sPS/mol-Tih (1a), 50 (2a)≪240 (1b). This opposite trend observed for the impact of the N-substituents in 1a,b on their performance in ethylene and styrene polymerization was similar to that observed for the imidazolidin-2-iminato analogues (1c–e). On the basis of the above homopolymerization results, the (co)polymerizations by 1a–e and 2a were conducted under ethylene pressure, and the results are summarized in Table 6 (ethylene 4atm, toluene/styrene 25/5mL, 25°C, runs 36–41). Although these complexes afforded syndiotactic polystyrene (SPS) with unimodal distributions, the resultant polymers prepared by the imidazolidin-2-iminato analogues (1d,e) were a mixture of the copolymer and SPS and/or polyethylene confirmed by both NMR spectra and DSC thermograms after careful fractional separation of all polymer samples: the activity of 1c was too low for a detailed analysis [21]. In contrast, note that the polymerization by the imidazolin-2-iminato analogues (1a,b,2a) afforded copolymers with uniform compositions confirmed by both GPC and DSC thermograms. In particular, 1b, which showed the highest catalytic activity for styrene polymerization, showed the highest activity in the copolymerization affording high molecular weight copolymer with uniform distribution (run 37). We thus explored the copolymerization by 1b in more detail. The results are summarized in Table 7 [23]. The catalytic activity in the copolymerization of the 1b–MAO catalyst system increased upon increasing the ethylene pressure employed, whereas the activity decreased upon increasing styrene concentration charged (runs 37, 42, 44–45). The resultant polymers were poly(ethylene-co-styrene)s in most cases except if the (co)polymerization was conducted under high styrene concentration (ethylene 4atm, run 43). The styrene contents by 1b were apparently low compared to those prepared by [Me2Si(C5Me4)(N t Bu)]TiCl2 (32.7mol%), ( t BuC5H4)TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (51.2mol%) under the same conditions (ethylene 4atm, styrene 10mL, run 42: 11.4mol%) [9d], suggesting that 1b showed rather inefficient styrene incorporation. Table 8 summarizes results for ethylene/styrene copolymerization using Cp′TiCl2[1,3- t Bu2(CHN)2CN] [Cp′=Cp (1a), tert-Bu-C5H4 (2a)]–MAO catalyst systems under various conditions. Importantly, the M n values in the resultant copolymers prepared by both 1a and 2a increased over the course of time as well as upon increasing the polymer yields consistently with relatively narrow molecular weight distributions, as depicted in Fig. 3 . The styrene contents in the resultant poly(ethylene-co-styrene)s increased upon increasing the styrene concentration, but the contents were rather low (6.2–16.3mol%): resonances ascribed to the isolated styrene incorporation were thus observed in the 13C NMR spectra (Fig. 4 , shown below) [24]. The apparent activities (on the basis of polymer yields) of 1a, 2a were not strongly affected by the styrene concentration employed. The activity of 2a stayed constant over the course of time (runs 38, 56–67), whereas the activity of 1a was initially high and remained constant for longer reaction hours (runs 36, and 46–53). In contrast, the resultant polymers were poly(ethylene-co-styrene)s with relatively broad molecular weight distributions (runs 54 and 55), if the copolymerizations by 1a were conducted under high styrene concentrations. A certain degree of chain transfer reaction would thus occur (probably by increased styrene insertion: content 25–26%), since the M n value did not increase over the time course. The first order relationship between the M n values and the polymer yields clearly indicate that the degree of chain transfer from Ti-alkyl to Al-alkyl was negligible and that the copolymerization proceeded in a living manner, as demonstrated by the Cp*TiCl2(NC t Bu2) [13c,e], ( t BuC5H4)TiCl2(3,5- i Pr2C3HN2) [16b]–MAO catalyst systems. Fig. 4 shows selected 13C NMR spectra for poly(ethylene-co-styrene)s prepared by 1a,b,2a–MAO catalyst systems (in 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane-d 2 at 110°C). Resonances ascribed to isolated styrene insertion were observed in the copolymer prepared by 1a and 2a (Fig. 4a, b, d), whereas resonances ascribed to alternating insertion (Sββ, Sαγ, Fig. 4c) were observed in trace amount in the copolymer prepared by 1b. The livingness by 1a diminished when the copolymerization was conducted under high styrene concentration probably due to increased styrene insertion (runs 54 and 55), and the styrene polymerization proceeded with a certain degree of chain transfer (run 33, Table 5). The facts thus suggest that a certain degree of the styrene insertion inhibited the chain transfer in this catalysis. 3 Concluding remark A series of half-titanocenes containing 1,3-disubstituted imidazolin-2-iminato ligands, Cp′TiCl2[1,3-R2(CHN)2CN] [Cp′=Cp (1), t BuC5H4 (2); R= t Bu (a), 2,6- i Pr2C6H3 (b)]–MAO catalyst systems, have been employed as the catalyst precursors especially for syndiospecific styrene polymerization, and ethylene copolymerization with 1-hexene and styrene in the presence of MAO cocatalyst. The results through this study are summarized as follows: (1) CpTiCl2[1,3- t Bu2(CHN)2CN] (1a) exhibited remarkable catalytic activity for ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization in the presence of MAO cocatalyst, affording poly(ethylene-co-1-hexene)s with ultrahigh molecular weights as well as with uniform molecular weight distributions (M n =1.07–1.31×106, M w/M n =1.43–1.82). Although the activity was higher than that observed for the imidazolidin-2-iminato analogue, CpTiCl2[1,3- t Bu2(CH2N)2CN] (1c) [21], the 1-hexene contents in the copolymers obtained with 1a were lower than those obtained with 1c as well as with the Cp-ketimide analogue under the same conditions [23]. The r E values in the ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization by 1a,b,2a were 9.56–9.62 (1a), 11.8 (1b), 17.4 (2a), respectively, and these values were much larger than those by 1c (4.95), Cp-Ket (4.5) [13b], [Me2Si(C5Me4)(N t Bu2)]TiCl2 (3.42) [9c], and Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (2.70) [9b,c], but were similar to those by the ordinary ansa zirconocenes (8.2–18.9) [24]. (2) Cp′TiCl2[1,3- t Bu2(CHN)2CN] [Cp′=Cp (1a), t BuC5H4 (2a)] are effective catalyst precursors for living ethylene/styrene copolymerization with moderate catalytic activities. In contrast, the Cp-imidazolidin-2-iminato analogues, CpTiCl2[1,3-R2(CH2N)2CN] [R= t Bu (1c), Ph (1d), 2,6-Me2C6H3 (1e)], afforded a mixture of copolymer and PE/SPS or exhibited negligible activity under the same conditions. The styrene contents (6.2–16.3mol%) in the copolymers were rather higher than those observed with ( t BuC5H4)TiCl2(3,5- i Pr2C3HN2) (1.4–6.0mol%) [16b] but similar to those with Cp*TiCl2(NC t Bu2) (7.2–11.2mol%) [13c,e]–MAO catalyst systems under similar conditions. On the basis of both the polymerization results and 13C NMR spectra of the resultant copolymers, it was suggested that a certain degree of the styrene insertion inhibited chain transfer in this catalysis, as observed in the above two examples. These results clearly suggest that the Cp′-imidazolin-2-iminato titanium complexes presented herein are very good catalyst precursors for ethylene (co)polymerization. Moreover, it is also demonstrated that the precise ligand modifications are the key for the successful (co)polymerization with remarkable catalytic activity as well as with efficient comonomer incorporation: this is considered as one of the unique characteristics for using modified nonbridged half-titanocenes as the catalyst for olefin polymerization [5]. We believe that the facts introduced here should be important for designing even more efficient catalyst for precise olefin polymerization. We are currently exploring more efficient catalysts by modification of both the cyclopentadienyl fragments and the anionic donor ligands, and we hope that we will establish the origin of the ligand effect for the efficient comonomer incorporation in the near future. 4 Experimental 4.1 General procedures All experiments were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere in a vacuum atmospheres drybox unless otherwise specified. All chemicals used were of reagent grade and were purified by the standard purification procedures. Anhydrous grade toluene (Kanto Chemical Co. Inc.) was transferred into a bottle containing molecular sieves (mixture of 3Å 1/16 and 4Å 1/8, and 13X 1/16) under a nitrogen stream in the drybox and were used without further purification. Anhydrous grade 1-hexene and 1-dodecene (Kanto Chemical Co. Inc.) were stored in bottles in the drybox in the presence of molecular sieves and were passed through an alumina short column before use. Styrene of reagent grade (Kanto Chemical Co. Inc.) was stored in a freezer after passing through an alumina short column under nitrogen flow in the drybox. Toluene and AlMe3 in the commercially available methylaluminoxane [PMAO-S 9.5wt% (Al) toluene solution, Tosoh Finechem Co.] were removed under reduced pressure (at ca. 50°C for removing toluene, AlMe3 and then heated at >100°C for 1h for completion) in the drybox to give white solids. Cp′TiCl2[1,3-R2(CHN)2CN] [Cp′=Cp (1), t BuC5H4 (2); R= t Bu (1,3-di-tert-butylimidazolin-2-imide, a), 2,6- i Pr2C6H3 (1,3-diisopropylphenyl imidazolin-2-imide, b)] were prepared according to previous reports [19a,b]. Ethylene for polymerization was of polymerization grade (purity >99.9%, Sumitomo Seika Co. Ltd.) and was used as-received. All 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV500 spectrometer (500.13MHz for 1H, 125.77MHz for 13C) and all chemical shifts are given in ppm and are referenced to SiMe4. Molecular weights and molecular weight distributions for the resultant polymers were measured by gel permeation chromatography (Tosoh HLC-8121GPC/HT) using a RI-8022 detector (for high temperature, Tosoh Co.) with a polystyrene gel column (TSK gel GMHHR-H HT×2, 30cm×7.8mm i.d.), ranging from <102 to <2.8×108 MW) at 140°C using o-dichlorobenzene containing 0.05 (wt/v%) 2,6-di-tert-butyl-p-cresol as the solvent. The molecular weight was calculated by a standard procedure based on the calibration with standard polystyrene samples. 4.2 Ethylene polymerization Ethylene polymerizations were conducted in toluene by using a 100mL scale autoclave. Toluene (29.0mL) and prescribed amount of MAO white solid were charged into the autoclave in the drybox, and the apparatus was placed under ethylene atmosphere (1atm). After the addition of a toluene solution (1.0mL) containing a prescribed amount of complex via a syringe, the reaction apparatus was pressurized to 5atm (total 6atm), and the mixture was stirred magnetically for 10min. After the above procedure, ethylene was purged, and the mixture was then poured into MeOH (150mL) containing HCl (10mL). The resultant polymer was collected on a filter paper by filtration and was adequately washed with MeOH and then dried in vacuo. 4.3 Syndiospecific polymerization of styrene Styrene (10mL) and the prescribed amount of MAO solid were added into the round bottom flask in the drybox at room temperature (25°C). A toluene solution (1.0mL) containing prescribed amount of complex was then added into the autoclave, and the mixture was magnetically stirred for 10min. The mixture was then taken out from the drybox, and was quickly terminated by adding EtOH (ca. 3mL). The mixture was then poured into EtOH (50mL) containing HCl (5mL). The resultant polymer was collected on a filter paper by filtration, and was adequately washed with EtOH, and was then dried in vacuo. According to the previous report [9a], the resultant polymer mixture was separated into two fractions, and atactic polystyrene prepared only by MAO itself was extracted with acetone; syndiotactic polystyrene prepared by titanium complexes–MAO catalyst was isolated as the acetone insoluble fraction. 4.4 Copolymerization of ethylene with 1-hexene, 1-dodecene, styrene Experimental procedures for the copolymerization of ethylene with 1-hexene were the same as those for the ethylene polymerization described above except that prescribed amount of 1-hexene was added into an autoclave. Experimental procedures for the ethylene/1-dodecene and ethylene/styrene copolymerizations were the same as those for the ethylene polymerizations except that a prescribed amount of 1-dodecene or styrene was charged and the total volume was set to 30mL. According to the previous report [9a,d], the resultant polymer mixture in the ethylene/styrene copolymerization might be separated into three fractions, and atactic polystyrene which was prepared only by MAO was extracted with acetone. Poly(ethylene-co-styrene) was extracted with tetrahydrofuran (THF), and polyethylene and/or syndiotactic polystyrene which were the by-product in this reaction was separated as THF insoluble fraction. The basic experimental procedure is as follows: The polymer sample obtained in the copolymerization experiment was added into a round bottom flask containing acetone equipped with a reflux condenser, and the mixture was refluxed for 6h to separate acetone soluble and insoluble fraction. The acetone insoluble fraction was then dried in vacuo, and was added into a round bottom flask containing THF equipped with a reflux condenser, and the mixture was refluxed for 6h to separate THF soluble and insoluble fractions. coredata.dc:description: Ethylene copolymerization with 1-hexene, styrene using half-titanocenes containing 1,3-dialkyl- and 1,3-diarylimidazolin-2-iminato ligands, Cp′TiCl2[1,3-R2(CHN)2CN] [Cp′=Cp (1), t BuC5H4 (2); R= t Bu (a), 2,6- i Pr2C6H3 (b)], have been explored in the presence of MAO cocatalyst. Complex 1a exhibited remarkable catalytic activity for ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization, affording ultrahigh molecular weight copolymers with uniform molecular weight distributions (M n =1.07–1.31×106, M w/M n =1.43–1.82). An opposite trend for effect of N-substituents in 1a,b toward the activity in ethylene and styrene homopolymerization was observed. The ethylene/styrene copolymerizations afforded poly(ethylene-co-styrene)s with uniform compositions and the polymerization by the t Bu analogues (1a,2a) proceeded in a living manner with moderate activities, whereas the imidazolidin-2-iminato analogues, CpTiCl2[1,3-R2(CH2N)2CN] (R= t Bu, Ph, 2,6-Me2C6H3), afforded a mixture of copolymer and homopolymers or exhibited negligible activity under the same conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Ethylene copolymerization by half-titanocenes containing imidazolin-2-iminato ligands–MAO catalyst systems
